case_name: Appellants v. State of Andhra Pradesh

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated September 28, 1956, of the former Andhra High Court at Guntur in Criminal Revision Case No. 241 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 28, 1956, of the former Andhra High Court at Guntur in Criminal Revision Case No. 241 of 1956.

facts.text: The case was heard on September 17, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. September 17. The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA J.-The only question that arises for determination in this appeal

facts.text: Judgment delivered by SINHA J.

anchor.surface_text: The following Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA J.-The only question that arises for determination in this appeal on a certificate

facts.text: 26 appellants committed to the Court of Session, Guntur Division, for trial under sections 147, 148, 323, 324 and 302 read with 34 and 149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The 26 appellants have been companymitted to the Court of Session, Guntur Division, to take their trial for offences punishable under ss. 147, 148, 323, 324 and 302, read with ss. 34 and 149, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: State of Andhra Pradesh is the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: They impleaded the State of Andhra Pradesh as the sole respondent. The Union of India has been allowed to intervene

facts.text: Union of India intervened because provisions of Central Act impugned.

anchor.surface_text: The Union of India has been allowed to intervene on an application made in that behalf in view of the fact that the provisions of the Central Act have been impugned as unconstitutional.

facts.text: Local police took cognizance of rioting with murder on December 22, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The local police took companynizance of a serious occurrence of rioting with murder on December 22, 1955.

facts.text: Police investigated the case and submitted charge-sheet under IPC sections to magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: The local police investigated the case, and after recording such evidence as it companyld companylect in respect of the occurrence, submitted a charge-sheet under the aforesaid sections of the Indian Penal Code, to the magistrate

facts.text: Magistrate committed accused under s. 207A CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The magistrate, following the procedure laid down in s. 207 A of the Code companymitted the persons shown in the chargesheet as the accused persons, to take their trial before the Court of Session.

facts.text: Accused filed revision applications to High Court under ss. 435 and 439 CrPC to quash commitment order.

anchor.surface_text: A number of applications in revision, under ss. 435 and 439 of the Code, were made on behalf of the accused persons, to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh, to quash the order of companymitment,

facts.text: Revisions argued s.207A unconstitutional due to discrimination.

anchor.surface_text: chiefly on the ground that the said order having been passed under the provisions of s. 207A of the Code  was void, as those provisions were unconstitutional for the reason that they introduced discrimination

facts.text: Krishna Rao J. dismissed revisions holding provisions constitutional.

anchor.surface_text: The revisional applications were heard by Krishna Rao J. who dismissed them, holding that the provisions impugned were number unconstitutional and that, therefore, the order of companymitment was valid in law.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate under Art. 134(1)(c) for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants applied for and obtained the necessary certificate under Art. 134 1  c  of the Constitution that the case was a fit one for appeal to this Court.

anchor.surface_text: The 26 appellants have been companymitted to the Court of Session, Guntur Division, to take their trial for offences punishable under ss. 147, 148, 323,
under ss. 147, 148, 323, 324 and 302, read with ss. 34 and 149, Indian Penal Code. They impleaded the State of Andhra Pradesh as the sole respondent.
deprived of the benefits under ss. 162 and 215 of the Code, and under ss. 27, 101 to 106 and 114-1ll.  g  of the Evidence Act.

issues.text: The only question that arises for determination in this appeal is the constitutionality of the provisions of ss. 207 and 207A, Code of Criminal Procedure

anchor.surface_text: The only question that arises for determination in this appeal on a certificate granted by the High Court of Andhra Pradesh at Hyderabad, under Art. 134(1)(c) of the Constitution, is the constitutionality of the provisions of ss. 207 and 207A, Code of Criminal Procedure  hereinaf

issues.text: Whether the provisions of ss. 207 and 207A violate Article 14 of the Constitution

Whether the classification between cases instituted on police report under s. 207A and other cases under Chapter XVIII satisfies the twin test of reasonable classification under Article 14 (intelligible differentia with rational nexus to the legislative object)
Whether the procedure under s. 207A is less advantageous to the accused and thus discriminatory compared to the procedure under s. 208 et seq.

anchor.surface_text: The arguments addressed to the High Court have been repeated in this Court and are to the effect that ss. 207 and 207A, as they now stand, provide for two separate procedures in the committing court, namely, (1) in respect of a case instituted on a police report for which the procedure specified in s. 207A is prescribed, and (2) in respect of any other proceeding, the procedure laid down in other provisions of Chapter XVIII is prescribed.

arguments.claim: The order of commitment under s.207A CrPC is void as the provisions of s.207A are unconstitutional because they introduce discrimination against accused in police charge-sheet cases.

anchor.surface_text: A number of applications in revision, under ss. 435 and 439 of the Code, were made on behalf of the accused persons, to the High Court of Andhra Pradesh, to quash the order of commitment, chiefly on the ground that the said order having been passed under the provisions of s. 207A of the Code was void, as those provisions were unconstitutional for the reason that they introduced discrimination

court_response_anchor.surface_text: of a case instituted on a police report is less advantageous to the accused than the other procedure. Thu

arguments.court_reasoning: Provisions held constitutional by High Court; affirmed by Supreme Court on reasonable classification grounds.

arguments.claim: ss. 207 and 207A provide for two separate procedures in the committing court; the procedure under s.207A for police report cases is less advantageous to the accused than the procedure for other cases under Chapter XVIII.

anchor.surface_text: The arguments addressed to the High Court have been repeated in this Court and are to the effect that ss. 207 and 207A, as they now stand, provide for two separate procedures in the committing court, namely, (1) in respect of a case instituted on a police report for which the procedure specified in s. 207A is prescribed, and (2) in respect of any other proceeding, the procedure laid down in other provisions of Chapter XVIII is prescribed.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: numbergrounds for companymitting the accused. It has further been argued that in the new procedure adopted in the impugned s. 207A, the accused person

arguments.court_reasoning: Assumed differences exist but not always prejudicial; introduced to simplify and expedite; existing classifications in CrPC valid.

arguments.claim: Under s.207A(2), accused deprived of right to apply for summoning witnesses/production of documents, unlike s.208(3) which allows accused to apply.

anchor.surface_text: By way of illustration, it was urged that under s. 208(3), it is open to an accused person to apply to the magistrate to issue process to compel the attendance of any witness or the production of any document, but sub-s. (2) of s. 207A, which corresponds to the provisions of s. 208(3), speaks only of the prosecution and not of the accused.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: a magistrate, has to furnish to the accused, free of companyt, a companyy of the report aforesaid, of the first information report and of all other d

arguments.court_reasoning: Procedure under s.207A adequate post-police investigation; classification reasonable for expedition.

arguments.claim: s.207A(4) refers only to prosecution evidence, unlike s.208(1) which includes evidence for prosecution or accused.

anchor.surface_text: Again, it is pointed out that sub-s. (4) of s. 207A, makes reference only to the prosecution evidence, whereas the corresponding s. 208(1) makes reference to the evidence that may be produced in support of the prosecution or on behalf of the accused.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: a magistrate, has to furnish to the accused, free of companyt, a companyy of the report aforesaid, of the first information report and of all other d

arguments.court_reasoning: Not prejudicial as police documents already supplied; magistrate can record other evidence if needed.

arguments.claim: No provisions in s.207A corresponding to s.209(2), s.213(2) for discharge of accused, or s.215 for quashing commitments.

anchor.surface_text: Similarly, it has been pointed out that there are no provisions in s. 207A corresponding to those of s. 209(2), and s. 213(2), empowering the magistrate to discharge the accused nor is there any provision in the impugned s. 207A corresponding to s. 215 relating to quashing of commitments.

arguments.court_reasoning: Magistrate can discharge if no grounds after considering documents; one stage sufficient post-police probe.

arguments.claim: s.207A(6) uses 'no grounds' for commitment unlike s.209(1) 'no sufficient grounds'.

anchor.surface_text: Further, it was pointed out that whereas s. 209(1) contains the words 'no sufficient grounds for committing the accused person', sub-s. (6) of s. 207A has the words 'no grounds for committing the accused'.

arguments.claim: Accused deprived of benefits under ss.162, 215 CrPC and ss.27, 101-106, 114(g) Evidence Act under s.207A procedure.

anchor.surface_text: It has further been argued that in the new procedure adopted in the impugned s. 207A, the accused person has been deprived of the benefits under ss. 162 and 215 of the Code, and under ss. 27, 101 to 106 and 114-lll. g of the Evidence Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: These apply at trial stage, not commitment; commitment procedure does not affect trial rights.

arguments.claim: Provisions of ss.207, 207A constitutional; order of commitment valid.

anchor.surface_text: The revisional applications were heard by Krishna Rao J. who dismissed them, holding that the provisions impugned were not unconstitutional and that, therefore, the order of commitment was valid in law.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees after applying Art.14 reasonable classification test.

arguments.claim: Differences in procedures exist but changes under Amending Act XXVI of 1955 not always to disadvantage of accused; aimed at simplifying and expediting trials.

anchor.surface_text: We shall assume for the purpose of examining the constitutionality of the impugned provisions of the amended Code that there are differences in the two kinds of procedure envisaged in Chapter XVIII of the Code, relating to commitment proceedings, but it is by no means clear that the changes introduced by the amending Act XXVI of 1955 are always to the disadvantage or prejudice of an accused person.

arguments.claim: CrPC has always classified procedures based on offence gravity, court powers, cognizable/non-cognizable, warrant/summons cases, etc.

anchor.surface_text: It is a well-known fact that the amending Act aforesaid introduced changes into the old Code with a view to simplifying and expediting procedure relating to trial of offences and to inquiries preceding such trials. It has also to be remembered that the Code has always prescribed different procedures for trial of offences varying with the gravity of the offences charged, or with the power of the court before which an accused person is placed on trial.

arguments.claim: Impugned provisions do not affect trial procedure, only commitment; cases on trial procedure changes irrelevant.
ss.207, 207A do not violate Art.14; classification between police report cases and complaint cases satisfies reasonable classification test (intelligible differentia + rational nexus).
Intelligible differentia: police cases have prior investigation by responsible public servant; rational nexus to speedy trial and justice administration.
Budhan Choudhry v. State of Bihar upholds similar classification under s.30 CrPC; applies here.
Matajog Dobey v. H.C. Bhari: discretionary power not necessarily discriminatory; applies to procedural differences.

holdings.text: For the reasons given above, it must be held that there is no discrimination and that the provisions of Art.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied Article 14 reasonable classification test: intelligible differentia in prior police investigation for s.207A cases vs. complaint cases under s.208 et seq., with rational nexus to legislative object of simplifying and expediting commitment proceedings for speedy justice.

holdings.text: the Legislature has provided for a clear classification between the two kinds of proceedings at the commitment stage based upon a very relevant consideration, namely, whether or not there has been a previous inquiry by a responsible public servant whose duty it is to discover crime and to bring criminals to speedy justice.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Intelligible differentia founded on presence/absence of prior police investigation under Chapter XIV CrPC; directly related to object of expeditious commitment and trial in cognizable serious offences.

holdings.text: This classification cannot be said to be unreasonable and not to have any relation to the object of the legislation, namely, a more speedy trial of offences without any avoidable delay.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rational nexus established between differentia (police vs private initiation) and purpose of 1955 amendment to expedite procedures in police-investigated cases involving public peace.

holdings.text: these provisions have not in any way affected the procedure at the trial. After a case has been committed to a Court of Session, the procedure for the trial of offences in either class of cases, remains the same.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Impugned sections concern only commitment inquiry stage, leaving trial rights intact; petitioner's cited disadvantages relate to commitment only, not trial where protections like ss.162 CrPC, Evidence Act apply.

holdings.text: all those cases which came up to this Court in which it was laid down that the law introduced substantial changes in the procedure at the trial, to the disadvantage of an accused person, have absolutely no relevance to the present case.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished precedents like Anwar Ali Sarkar etc. as they involved trial-stage changes, unlike here where only pre-trial commitment streamlined.

holdings.text: a discretionary power is not necessarily discriminatory.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied holding from Matajog Dobey v. H.C. Bhari to procedural variations under CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Applying the principles laid down by this Court to the case in hand to judge whether or no there has been objectionable discrimination, there could not be the least doubt that the Legislature has provided for a clear classification between the two kinds of proceedings at the companymitment stage based upon a very relevant companysideration, namely, whether or number there has been a previous inquiry by a responsible public servant whose duty it is to discover crime and to bring criminals to speedy justice. This basis of classification is clearly companynected with the underlying principle of admin- istration of justice that an alleged criminal should be placed on his trial as soon after the companymission of the crime as circumstances of the case would permit. This classification cannot be said to be unreasonable and number to have any relation to the object of the legislation, namely, a more speedy trial of offences without any avoidable delay. For the reasons given above, it must be held that there is numberdiscrimination and that the provisions of Art.

outcome.relief_summary: Constitutionality of ss. 207 and 207A CrPC upheld; no discrimination under Art. 14; challenge rejected

anchor.surface_text: Applying the principles laid down by this Court to the case in hand to judge whether or no there has been objectionable discrimination, there could not be the least doubt that the Legislature has provided for a clear classification between the two kinds of proceedings at the companymitment stage based upon a very relevant companysideration, namely, whether or number there has been a previous inquiry by a responsible public servant whose duty it is to discover crime and to bring criminals to speedy justice. This basis of classification is clearly companynected with the underlying principle of admin- istration of justice that an alleged criminal should be placed on his trial as soon after the companymission of the crime as circumstances of the case would permit. This classification cannot be said to be unreasonable and number to have any relation to the object of the legislation, namely, a more speedy trial of offences without any avoidable delay. For the reasons given above, it must be held that there is numberdiscrimination and that the provisions of Art.
